articles.title: Then and Now: Change in Isla Vista After May 23
articles.description: Distraught I.V. residents protest outside IV Deli, urging news crews to leave their community.
articles.content:
On the left, thousands of students and I.V. residents gathered together at Manzanita Beach for an Isla Vista Paddle Out Memorial on May 28, 2014. On the right, the beach on a typical quiet day.


On the left, police officers gather at a crime scene near the Loop Apartments in the aftermath of the May 23 shootings. On the right, Pizza My Heart is filled with patrons on an evening.


On the left, distraught I.V. residents protest outside IV Deli, urging news crews to leave their community. On the right, IV Deli’s windows advertise the establishment’s various deals.


On the left, police officers taped off the final crash site of the shooter’s black BMW on Del Playa Drive. On the right, a row of cars is parked at the street corner.


On the left, a segment of Trigo Road in front of the Loop Apartments is taped off. On the right, an Amazon store has closed for the evening.
Print

articles.title: In Photos: TASA’s 12th Annual Night Market
articles.description: In case you missed the TASA festival here's some food to make your mouth water
articles.content:
The TASA Annual Night Market is a tradition surpassing a decade on our campus that provides a place to experience cultural cuisine. The flavors are big and the food is abundant. If you missed the event here are some mouth-watering photos to get you through another year.

Photos by Pei Chiao Lin and Jenny Luo

A sweet treat to start the event, Mango with purple sticky rice. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
They’re almost to good to be true. Straight out of a fairytale: Tanghulu (candied fruit) Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
Try something other than boba this time. Green jelly milk drink. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
We don’t want none unless you got buns hun. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
Ooodles of Noodles. Yakisoba. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
A friendly member serving up deliciousness. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
“Bap, Bap” straight to the top. Kimbap. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
Comfort food turned it up a notch. Curry with rice. Pei Chiao Lin/Daily Nexus
Are you man enough? Fish balls with siracha. Pei Chiao Lin/Daily Nexus
The crowds were abundant at the market. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus
A skill not everyone can possess. The making of popcorn chicken. Jenny Luo/Daily Nexus

articles.title: In Photos: A.S. Election Results 2017
articles.description: Campus United swept the 2017 Associated Students elections, winning 16 of 25 A.S. Senate seats and four of five executive seats.
articles.content:
Campus United swept the 2017 Associated Students elections, winning 16 of 25 A.S. Senate seats and four of five executive seats.

More than 200 were in attendance for the live election result reveal at the Hub. Six Isla Vista Party members became A.S. senators, and Jack Tannenbaum, an independent candidate, the student advocate general. All 33 reaffirmation bills were passed, as well as a fee increase for the Community Financial Fund and the Legal Resource Center. Here are the photos from last Thursday’s event:

Photos by Daily Nexus photographers.

Campus United members Adham Btaddini (left) and Deepika Chandrashekar (right) embrace as they sweep 16 of 25 A.S. Senate seats. Both ran for off-campus senator seats; Btaddini won, while Chandrashekar did not. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Jorge Santos (left) and Steven Ho (right) were two of nine Isla Vista Party candidates to win seats on A.S. Senate on Thursday. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Kristin Hsu (center) thanked her mentor Matthew Santos (left) for her election as external vice president of statewide affairs on Thursday. Alex Yam / Daily Nexus
The Isla Vista Party is the fifth campus political party to emerge in the past two years. Alex Yam / Daily Nexus
Campus United won 16 of 25 A.S. Senate seats and four of five executive seats. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Campus United swept A.S. Elections for the second year in a row, winning four out of five executive seats and a supermajority of the seats on A.S. Senate. Alex Yam / Daily Nexus
Grecia Martinez from the Isla Vista Party was one of six candidates who ran for the four College of Letters and Science seats on Senate. She won the most votes on Thursday. Alex Yam / Daily Nexus
Members of the Isla Vista Party look on as results are announced. Nine of 25 A.S. Senate seats were filled by members of the party. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Adham Btaddini was one of 16 Campus United candidates to win seats on A.S. Senate on Thursday night. Alex Yam / Daily Nexus
A.S. Elections Board officials said 7,220 students turned out to vote this week, accounting for nearly 36 percent of the undergraduate student body. Alex Yam / Daily Nexus
Hieu Le (center) became A.S. President last Thursday, winning out over Nawar Nemeh, Isla Vista Party candidate, and write-in candidate Navpreet Khabra. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Campus United won 16 of 25 A.S. Senate seats and four of five executive seats.

articles.title: In Photos: Deltopia Weekend 2017
articles.description: The Nexus takes a look at this year's Deltopia, Isla Vista's informal street party.
articles.content:
2017 marks the seventh year of Deltopia, Isla Vista’s annual Spring Break celebration on Del Playa Drive. This past weekend saw 6,000 to 8,000 people attend the informal street party, with 42 arrests, 68 citations and 14 medical transports, still down from the 20,000 to 25,000 attending, 130 arrested, 190 cited and 50 medically transported in 2014.

A UC Santa Barbara student fell off an oceanside balcony Saturday afternoon and sustained “moderate injuries,” authorities said.

Associated Students Program Board hosted on Saturday night its third annual installment of The Warm Up featuring artists RL Grime and Destructo.

Photos by Daily Nexus photographers

A female student fell off a cliff Saturday and was taken to the hospital where she was treated for “moderate injuries.” The student was one of 14 medical transports on Saturday. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus
RL Grime performed in the ThunderDome Saturday night as part of A.S. Program Board’s The Warm Up. Francisco Barrera / Daily Nexus
Deltopia crowds were estimated to be as low as 6,000 and as high as 8,000. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus
While crowds were larger than last year, they were significantly lower than in 2014, when approximately 20,000 to 25,000 people attended. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus
Some on the I.V. Community Service District (CSD) Board of Directors believe that a sanctioned event with a festival ordinance would make the community and its students safer, especially after the 2014 Deltopia Riots. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus
Police shut down approximately 12 parties on Saturday due to safety concerns and alleged law violations. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus
Police walked through Isla Vista patrolling the Saturday party scene. Deltopia 2017 saw 42 arrests and 68 citations. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus
This is the first year Deltopia fell on the same weekend as Spring Insight, a day for prospective students to come to UCSB and learn about the university. As a result, UCPD opted to not use fencing on El Colegio and around residence halls. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus
The Warm Up’s RL Grime concert sold out to 6,000 students. Francisco Barrera / Daily Nexus
This is the seventh year Deltopia has taken place on Del Playa Drive, after the county closed access to the beaches for Floatopia, the original Spring Break party. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus

articles.title: In Photos: 32nd Annual Santa Barbara International Film Festival
articles.description: Held in various venues across downtown Santa Barbara, this year’s Santa Barbara International Film Festival was one for the books. Groundbreaking works such as ‘Loving’, ‘Moonl...
articles.content:
Held in various venues across downtown Santa Barbara, this year’s Santa Barbara International Film Festival was one for the books. Groundbreaking works such as ‘Loving’, ‘Moonlight’, and ‘La La Land’ were honored throughout the week, and the stars of these films lit up the central coast skyline.

Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Loving actor Ruth Negga was one of eight actors awarded the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival. Jose Arturo Ochoa / Daily Nexus
Moonlight actor Mahershala Ali (right) was one of eight actors awarded the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival. Jose Arturo Ochoa / Daily Nexus
Lion actor Dev Patel was one of eight actors awarded the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival. Jose Arturo Ochoa / Daily Nexus
Fences actor Stephen McKinley Henderson was one of eight actors awarded the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival. Jose Arturo Ochoa / Daily Nexus
Hidden Figures and Moonlight actor Janelle Monáe was one of eight actors awarded the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival. Jose Arturo Ochoa / Daily Nexus
Nocturnal Animals actor Aaron Taylor Johnson was one of eight actors awarded the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival. Jose Arturo Ochoa / Daily Nexus
Ryan Gosling on the red carpet. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
SBIFF Executive Director Roger Durling. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Cara Santana. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Ava DuVernay. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Emma Stone was awarded the Outstanding Performers Award, alongside Ryan Gosling. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Damian Chazelle was one of the many awarded the Outstanding Directors of the Year Award. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
Jesse Metcalfe with fiancé Cara Santana on the red carpet. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus
The Cinema Vanguard Award honored Casey Affleck and Michelle Williams. Min Xie / Daily Nexus

articles.title: In Photos: Trump Inauguration Walkout
articles.description: Nearly 500 students gathered at Campbell Hall on Friday to protest the inauguration of Donald Trump, the 45th President of the United States. Students were joined by faculty, residents of Isla Vista,...
articles.content:
Nearly 500 students gathered at Campbell Hall on Friday to protest the inauguration of Donald Trump, the 45th President of the United States. Students were joined by faculty, residents of Isla Vista, as well as those who supported President Donald Trump. Here are a few snapshots from the rainy day:

Photos by Daily Nexus Photographers

Activists gather in front of Campbell Hall before the walkout. William Emmons / Daily Nexus

articles.title: In Photos: Snowglobe 2016
articles.description: This year’s Snowglobe Festival, held in the chilly mountains of Lake Tahoe, boasted one of its most ambitious lineups yet. Lil Yachty and The Chainsmokers are two of the hottest crossover succes...
articles.content:
This year’s Snowglobe Festival, held in the chilly mountains of Lake Tahoe, boasted one of its most ambitious lineups yet. Lil Yachty and The Chainsmokers are two of the hottest crossover successes on pop radio, while Flume is an electronic mainstay. Tucked away in one of California’s favorite getaway spots, Snowglobe is its own winter wonderland.

Photos by Riley Esguerra / Daily Nexus

articles.title: In Photos: Students March Through Isla Vista After Trump Announced President
articles.description: Over a thousand UC Santa Barbara students marched through Isla Vista early Wednesday morning and gathered underneath Storke Tower, protesting the election of Donald Trump. Another rally in response to...
articles.content:
Over a thousand UC Santa Barbara students marched through Isla Vista early Wednesday morning and gathered underneath Storke Tower, protesting the election of Donald Trump. Another rally in response to Trump’s victory was held at 12 p.m. at Storke Plaza on Thursday.

Photos by Daily Nexus Photographers

A student yells into a megaphone while joining the protest on Del Playa. Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

The crowd started in San Nicolas and moved to I.V. and back to Storke Plaza. Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

A Trump supporter proudly waved an American flag while others shouted, “Light it on fire!” Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

Nearing 1:30 p.m., the protest could also be heard from at least the 66 block of Isla Vista. Jenny Luo / Daily Nexus

 

New protestors joined the crowd with each step. Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

Students displayed their solidarity by waving Mexican flags as well as American flags. Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

Protestors chanted “Fuck Donald Trump,” among other things, as they walked. Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

Students continued to make their way through Pardall tunnel. Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

After passing around the Loop in I.V. and heading back through Pardall Road, the protest ended at the base of Storke tower. Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

A student behind the speakers sported a Mexican flag, prompting chants of “Viva la Mexico.” Will Tran / Daily Nexus

 

The Student Activist Network offered students a megaphone and a safe space for peaceful protest. Pei Chiao Lin / Daily Nexus

 

The protest reached 1,000 students by the time it ended at 2 a.m. Pei Chiao Lin / Daily Nexus

Print

articles.title: In Photos: Yangs Walkabout Ghostly Streets
articles.description: Chancellor Henry T. Yang and Dilling Yang joined Daily Nexus editor in chief Megan Mineiro on Monday for a walkabout Isla Vista. The Yangs accompany the Nexus each year to talk with students about...
articles.content:
Chancellor Henry T. Yang and Dilling Yang joined Daily Nexus editor in chief Megan Mineiro on Monday for a walkabout Isla Vista. The Yangs accompany the Nexus each year to talk with students about their Halloween shenanigans. This year they ventured down deserted streets, witnesses to the quiet Halloween that starkly contrasted the rowdiness of partygoers common in years past.

Photos by Dustin Harris

Neither music nor partygoers could be found on Del Playa Drive Monday night. Law enforcement reported just 46 citations and 26 arrests over the course of Halloween weekend, the majority for public intoxication or violation of the festival noise ordinance.

 

The Yangs interacted with the few students in costume walking down Del Playa. Nexus EIC Megan Mineiro dressed as Joyce Byers from the popular Netflix series Stranger Things, while the Chancellor said he was disguised as a grandfather.

 

Daily Nexus EIC Megan Mineiro and Chancellor Yang stopped to talk with UCPD officers on patrol, as Officer Bly [center] reminisced about his time as a student in I.V.

The Yangs took the time to stop and chat with multiple students they recognized during their walkabout I.V.

 

While 13,000 partygoers packed the streets of I.V. in 2013, numbers have since declined to a couple thousand in 2014 and just over 500 in 2015.

 

Of the few students who took to the streets Monday night some used costumes as an opportunity to make political statements.

Print

articles.title: In Photos: Blue-Green Rivalry Ends in Tie
articles.description: Harder Stadium filled with 11,424 people on Saturday for the Blue-Green Rivalry, breaking records as the largest crowd in the country this season for a men’s soccer game.
articles.content:
Josue Salgado clears the ball after a clean slide tackle. Eric Swenson / Daily Nexus

Kevin Feucht stumbles over Cal Poly defenders. Dustin Harris / Daily Nexus

Nick DePuy and Jan Ilskens receive hugs while preparing for a corner kick. Eric Swenson / Daily Nexus

Members of the audience come up to the side of the field, cheering for the camera. Eric Swenson / Daily Nexus

Ahinga Selemani rushes to keep the ball from rolling out of bounds. Dustin Harris / Daily Nexus

Sean Dhillon crosses the ball. Eric Swenson / Daily Nexus

Ahinga Selemani races for control of the ball. Eric Swenson / Daily Nexus

Fans cheer and tortillas are thrown after a favorable call. Eric Swenson / Daily Nexus

After leaping over a defender, Jeff Quezada heads the ball upfield. Dustin Harris / Daily Nexus

The clean up crews had to work hard to keep the field clear of tortillas thrown throughout the game. McLane Brown / Daily Nexus

Jan Ilskens wrestles the ball away from Cal Poly’s Justin Dhillon during the last minutes of the match. Courtesy of Kenneth Song

Titouan Le Roux anticipates his next move as the game goes into overtime. Dustin Harris / Daily Nexus

UCSB’s Lamar Batista and Cal Poly goalie Eric Kam battle to control the ball during the final minutes of the double-overtime match. Courtesy of Kenneth Song

Nick DePuy out-maneuvers the SLO defense. Eric Swenson / Daily Nexus

At the end of two overtime periods, the match was still scoreless. Dustin Harris / Daily Nexus

UCSB librarian Margaret Rankin collects tortillas after the game. Dustin Harris / Daily Nexus

UCSB Guest Services crew pick up tortillas after the match. Courtesy of Kenneth Song

articles.title: In Photos: IV Around the World
articles.description: Gauchos captured their favorite moments from summer travels, near and far, from right here in Isla Vista to exotic cities across continents.
articles.content:
Gauchos captured their favorite moments from summer travels, near and far, from right here in Isla Vista to exotic cities across continents.

Third-year Taylor Daoust took a helicopter to the top of Fox Glacier while studying abroad in New Zealand with fellow Gauchos Audrey Berg and Amanda Schweitzer.

Third-year Maya Longtin captured hot steam rising from the Grand Prismatic Spring in Yellowstone National Park.

Fourth-year Rawan Sultan rode a camel and visited the ancient pyramids in Cairo, Egypt.

First-year Christine Choi ventured into Harry Potter World at Universal Studios Hollywood.

Fourth-year Brittany Tholan did marine research with a lab on campus and witnessed a couple of breathtaking, common dolphins right in our own backyard- just offshore of IV Reef.

Daily Nexus Photographer Stephen Manga jumped off a 22-foot cliff in Oahu, Hawaii.

Fourth-year Nate Fritter visited North Lake Tahoe with family.

News Editor Supriya Yelimeli spent a week in India for her cousin’s wedding. Pre-festivity market crawl in Bengaluru, India pictured.

Second-year Josephine Cheng reached the peak of the Sea to Sky Gondola overlooking Squamish River in Vancouver, Canada.

Third-year Kaitlyn Haberlin went hiking around Silver Lake in the Eastern Sierras.

Print

articles.title: In Photos: Black Lives Matter Rally
articles.description: Over 150 people attended a rally organized by Santa Barbara High School students from the local chapter of Ethnic Studies Now on Thursday.
articles.content:
Over 150 people attended a rally organized by Santa Barbara High School students from the local chapter of Ethnic Studies Now on Thursday. UC Santa Barbara students, parents, children and local residents marched from State Street to Stearn’s Wharf with signs and loudspeakers to call for an end to police brutality in the United States. Photos by Jenny Luo.
